DENOUNCED BY HAYS

Need of Freedom

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 29. 1927

DEBATERS SUFEER
DEFEAT IN SOUTH
Taking the affirmative side
of the question, "Resolved,
That there be a uniform marriage and divorce law for the
United States," the Johns
Hopkins Intercollegiate Debating Team, consisting of
Eugene O'Dunne, Jr., and
Donald C. Niles, was defeated
both on Friday night by Davidson College at Charlotte,
N. C., and on Saturday night
by Wake Forest College, at
Raleigh, in the same State.
The decision in both debates was two to one.

To.the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.

As the new Johns Hopkins will ostensibly draw its student
body from all over the world, it is difficult to understand how the
changing of the curriculum of one preparatory school can be a
,
leading factor in the inauguration of the New Plan. It would be
interesting to know. how many of the present local freshmen and
sophomores would have entered Johns Hopkins under the New
Plan instead of going to the University of Maryland or elsewhere.
If more of them would have done so in either case, bridging the
gap between local needs and the new organization of this University is an important consideration. If, however, most of these
men should not have wanted to specialize, and this we do not
know, there is no reason other than financial to hinder the immediate institution of the New Plan.
If a large number of the students at Johns Hopkins will continue to be residents of Baltimore, it is right, in deference to them,
that the plan should be worked out gradually. But if the number
of Baltimore men who will study at the University is no larger
than the number of men from other cities, catering at the present
time to Baltimore's needs is, in the long run, useless.

RICHMOND TRUST BUILDING RICHMOND, VA.

W. W. WALKER

Dr. David E. Weiglein's recent announcement that the Baltimore City College is preparing to take over the work of the
first two years of college brings the New Plan one step closer to
realization. According to Dr. Goodnow, the chief obstacles in
the path are a plethora of funds and a sense of civic duty which
compels the undergraduate school to "carry on" for the sake of
Baltimore youth.

We could not very well disapprove of the ideal and the substance of the New Plan, for if it materializes in actuality as it is
apparently existent in Dr. Goodnow's mind, the needs of the
municipality of Baltimore cannot be fairly weighed against the
benefits of scholarship that will accrue from its operation. Therefore, any consideration of local claims is really complimentary, if
not perfunctory.

WILL MOST OF THE NEW PLAN STUDENTS
BE BALTIMORE RESIDENTS?

The former reason is both valid and logical. And what is
probably more important, it is necessary. But, in spite of all
that has been said upon the sutect, we are prone to doubt the
forcefulness of the second. Prolonging the death of the College
of Arts and Sciences is in reality of very little benefit to those
young men of this city who want a general cultural .education.
After all, they will, eventually, have to attend college away from
home, at a cost that will deprive many of them of such an education at all. It is true that a few will find the extended high school
course sufficient, and will have no desire to attend college for the
remaining two years. Others, however, will want a broader education than they can find in the extra curriculum of the City College, but will not feel that they desire- to specialize. This will
apply particularly to men who want to enter the law, journalism,
or similar professions.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 29, 1927
ADAMS CONTEST SLATED DR. ROBINSON PLANS TO TRAVEL
FOR NEXT ASSEMBLY
AND STUDY IN
Ness, Sands, Stevenson, Waters, and
Driver to Try for Award

,11

The feature of this week's assembly will be the annual public speaking contest for the Adams Medal.
This award is handsomely engraved
in gold and is presented as part of
a watch fob. It is given in honor of
the late Professor Herbert Baxter
Adams, who, for twenty-five years,
was instructor in history and political economy at Hopkins, and who
was very instrumental in the founding of the American Historical Society.
Two weeks ago the entrants in
the contest, who are required to be
either sophomores or students entered in the course known as, Public
Speaking 1, delivered before Doctor
French, a memorized extract from
some modern speech.. From this
group Doctor French selected P. W.
Ness, E. G. Sands, F. R. Stevenson, C. E. Waters, and W. a
Driver as eligible to compete for the
prize. These men will deliver the
same speeches before the assembly
which they delivered befofe Doctor
French.
• J. Cary Thompson, who, as a
11-mmber of the Debating Council, is
in charge of the contest, has announced that each speaker will be
allowed seven minutes in which to
deliver his address. The Debating
Council will select the judges some
time before Thursday.
I. Evans Rodgers was winner of
the Adams Medal last year.

To the Editor of the NEWS-LF,TTER.
Dear Sir:
Outside of finding Mr. Hayes a
delightful and entertaining speaker,
how many of the students that
heard him in assembly agreed wholly with his views and were in sympathy with his attacks on our
"moral" and God-fearing Americans?
wonder.

Yours sincerely,

This year the Dormitory was the
scene of more Freshman-Sophoniore skirmishes than it has been in
Previous years. It appears as though
the first and second year residents
took this class spirit business to
heart. An egg encounter by the
entry "B" boys appropriately opened the banquet season at the Dormitory. We announce with great
Pleasure that a few graduate students were egg victims.
There was much anxiety last
Tuesday evening among the residents concerning Osserman's disapPearance. Osserman has always
seemed to be a peaceful sort of chap
and his friends feared foul play.
There were many strange and wild
rumors as to how the great Osseritlan was kidnapped. Some thought
that he was taken away in an American Express truck, which was seen
iO front of the Dormitory late Tuesday afternoon, while others were
Positive that he had been bound
and rolled away.
Tuesday the bulletin board in the
Main hall of the dormitory was covered with notices for fellows to call
their parents and receive a lecture
01-1 the evils of taking part in the
banquet scenes.
The most objectionable thing
about banquet season is that it reMinds juniors and seniors of their
banquets and many of them feel
Obliged to relate them to you in
Rreat detail.

Tariff Situation Acute

"The three fundamental problems
in the Chinese situation are, tariff,
extra-territoriality rights, and treaty
ports." There has been considerable
discussion over the tariff which is
at present a five per cent ad valorem
duty. At the time of its foundation

A particularly good range
at $50

it was not unjust. Today, however,
it gives an opportunity to industrial.

Conference, a meeting was
held about two years ago to change

ington

the tariff. Consequently, a duty of
twelve and a half per cent will go
into effect in 1929.
Extra-territoriality rights came
into being in the early years of
China's intercourse with western nations. They were primarily caused
by the great difference between Chinese and Western law. The Chinese
claim that this difference is now
done away with, owing to the modernizing of the Chinese courts; and
they want to do away with extraterritoriality rights. Russia, Germany, and Belgium have done this
with varying results. "There are
many defects in the old system,"
said Dr. Blakeslee, "but in my opinion it is not yet time to do away
with it at least in a modified form."
England and Japan have reversed
their policy of force. China, on
achieving unity, will find the United
States and other nations ready to listen t6 her demands.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 29. 1927

DEBATERS SUFEER
DEFEAT IN SOUTH
Taking the affirmative side
of the question, "Resolved,
That there be a uniform marriage and divorce law for the
United States," the Johns
Hopkins Intercollegiate Debating Team, consisting of
Eugene O'Dunne, Jr., and
Donald C. Niles, was defeated
both on Friday night by Davidson College at Charlotte,
N. C., and on Saturday night
by Wake Forest College, at
Raleigh, in the same State.
The decision in both debates was two to one.

To.the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.

As the new Johns Hopkins will ostensibly draw its student
body from all over the world, it is difficult to understand how the
changing of the curriculum of one preparatory school can be a
,
leading factor in the inauguration of the New Plan. It would be
interesting to know. how many of the present local freshmen and
sophomores would have entered Johns Hopkins under the New
Plan instead of going to the University of Maryland or elsewhere.
If more of them would have done so in either case, bridging the
gap between local needs and the new organization of this University is an important consideration. If, however, most of these
men should not have wanted to specialize, and this we do not
know, there is no reason other than financial to hinder the immediate institution of the New Plan.
If a large number of the students at Johns Hopkins will continue to be residents of Baltimore, it is right, in deference to them,
that the plan should be worked out gradually. But if the number
of Baltimore men who will study at the University is no larger
than the number of men from other cities, catering at the present
time to Baltimore's needs is, in the long run, useless.

RICHMOND TRUST BUILDING RICHMOND, VA.

W. W. WALKER

Dr. David E. Weiglein's recent announcement that the Baltimore City College is preparing to take over the work of the
first two years of college brings the New Plan one step closer to
realization. According to Dr. Goodnow, the chief obstacles in
the path are a plethora of funds and a sense of civic duty which
compels the undergraduate school to "carry on" for the sake of
Baltimore youth.

We could not very well disapprove of the ideal and the substance of the New Plan, for if it materializes in actuality as it is
apparently existent in Dr. Goodnow's mind, the needs of the
municipality of Baltimore cannot be fairly weighed against the
benefits of scholarship that will accrue from its operation. Therefore, any consideration of local claims is really complimentary, if
not perfunctory.

WILL MOST OF THE NEW PLAN STUDENTS
BE BALTIMORE RESIDENTS?

The former reason is both valid and logical. And what is
probably more important, it is necessary. But, in spite of all
that has been said upon the sutect, we are prone to doubt the
forcefulness of the second. Prolonging the death of the College
of Arts and Sciences is in reality of very little benefit to those
young men of this city who want a general cultural .education.
After all, they will, eventually, have to attend college away from
home, at a cost that will deprive many of them of such an education at all. It is true that a few will find the extended high school
course sufficient, and will have no desire to attend college for the
remaining two years. Others, however, will want a broader education than they can find in the extra curriculum of the City College, but will not feel that they desire- to specialize. This will
apply particularly to men who want to enter the law, journalism,
or similar professions.

The feature of this week's assembly will be the annual public speaking contest for the Adams Medal.
This award is handsomely engraved
in gold and is presented as part of
a watch fob. It is given in honor of
the late Professor Herbert Baxter
Adams, who, for twenty-five years,
was instructor in history and political economy at Hopkins, and who
was very instrumental in the founding of the American Historical Society.
Two weeks ago the entrants in
the contest, who are required to be
either sophomores or students entered in the course known as, Public
Speaking 1, delivered before Doctor
French, a memorized extract from
some modern speech.. From this
group Doctor French selected P. W.
Ness, E. G. Sands, F. R. Stevenson, C. E. Waters, and W. a
Driver as eligible to compete for the
prize. These men will deliver the
same speeches before the assembly
which they delivered befofe Doctor
French.
• J. Cary Thompson, who, as a
11-mmber of the Debating Council, is
in charge of the contest, has announced that each speaker will be
allowed seven minutes in which to
deliver his address. The Debating
Council will select the judges some
time before Thursday.
I. Evans Rodgers was winner of
the Adams Medal last year.

This year the Dormitory was the
scene of more Freshman-Sophoniore skirmishes than it has been in
Previous years. It appears as though
the first and second year residents
took this class spirit business to
heart. An egg encounter by the
entry "B" boys appropriately opened the banquet season at the Dormitory. We announce with great
Pleasure that a few graduate students were egg victims.
There was much anxiety last
Tuesday evening among the residents concerning Osserman's disapPearance. Osserman has always
seemed to be a peaceful sort of chap
and his friends feared foul play.
There were many strange and wild
rumors as to how the great Osseritlan was kidnapped. Some thought
that he was taken away in an American Express truck, which was seen
iO front of the Dormitory late Tuesday afternoon, while others were
Positive that he had been bound
and rolled away.
Tuesday the bulletin board in the
Main hall of the dormitory was covered with notices for fellows to call
their parents and receive a lecture
01-1 the evils of taking part in the
banquet scenes.
The most objectionable thing
about banquet season is that it reMinds juniors and seniors of their
banquets and many of them feel
Obliged to relate them to you in
Rreat detail.

Tariff Situation Acute

"The three fundamental problems
in the Chinese situation are, tariff,
extra-territoriality rights, and treaty
ports." There has been considerable
discussion over the tariff which is
at present a five per cent ad valorem
duty. At the time of its foundation

A particularly good range
at $50

it was not unjust. Today, however,
it gives an opportunity to industrial.

Conference, a meeting was
held about two years ago to change

ington

the tariff. Consequently, a duty of
twelve and a half per cent will go
into effect in 1929.
Extra-territoriality rights came
into being in the early years of
China's intercourse with western nations. They were primarily caused
by the great difference between Chinese and Western law. The Chinese
claim that this difference is now
done away with, owing to the modernizing of the Chinese courts; and
they want to do away with extraterritoriality rights. Russia, Germany, and Belgium have done this
with varying results. "There are
many defects in the old system,"
said Dr. Blakeslee, "but in my opinion it is not yet time to do away
with it at least in a modified form."
England and Japan have reversed
their policy of force. China, on
achieving unity, will find the United
States and other nations ready to listen t6 her demands.
